ygData.subject: Re: variable-T,P reactor
ygData.msgSnippet: I saw that the Reactor and FlowReactor classes still only have isothermal and adiabatic options.  I d like to implement a variable T-P model, preferably

I saw that the Reactor and FlowReactor classes still only have
isothermal a=
nd adiabatic options.  I'd like to implement a variable
T-P model, preferab=
ly through the Python interface.

Does anyone know of a straightforward way=
 to implement a variable T-P
reactor in Python?  I was thinking about using=
 the stiff ODE
integrator in SciPy, but that requires use of NumPy and migh=
t conflict
with Cantera's use of Numarray.  Do you think this would work, o=
r is
the Matlab approach below still recommended.

--Kevin

--- In cantera@=
yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> Paul,
> 
> Current=
ly using the Cantera Reactor class this is hard to do.  It 
> allows you to=
 fix T, or solve the energy equation, but it doesn't allow 
> specified T(t=
ime), or P(time).
> 
> For now, probably the best thing to do is to write t=
he ODEs yourself, 
> and use Cantera to evaluate the terms in the equations=
. See, for 
> example, the Cantera MATLAB demos "ignite.m", "ignite2.m", an=
d the 
> function in the Cantera toolbox "reactor_ode.m" for an example of =
this 
> approach. The MATLAB stiff ODE integrator used in these demos works=
 
> fine for these problems.
> 
> I have actually written a new class "Flow=
Reactor" that is closer to 
> what you want, but it is not ready for releas=
e yet.   It is designed to 
> simulate reacting plug flow in a channel, and=
 includes compressibility 
> effects, heat loss, friction, etc.  I'll make =
sure to allow specified 
> T(x) and P(x) as an option.  I don't know precis=
ely when this will be 
> ready for release - maybe in a couple of weeks.
> =

> Dave
> 
> 
> On Nov 8, 2005, at 8:04 AM, peyelvington wrote:
> 
> > Dear=
 Group,
> >
> > I would like to simulate a zero-d, variable-T,P reactor. I =
have
> > profiles of T(time) and P(time) from a separate fluid-dynamic
> > =
calculation of flow in a probe and sample line. I'm assuming plug flow
> > =
and so using the zero-d eqns with time in the batch system really
> > repre=
senting residence time along the PFR (i.e. sample line). (I'm
> > trying to=
 predict measurement errors due to chemical conversion in
> > sample system=
s used to measure trace gases from jet aircraft engines.)
> > I have a tabl=
e of values for time, T and P that I would like to
> > interpolate to get t=
he current reactor conditions.
> >
> > Does anyone have a Python script to =
model a variable-T,P reactor or
> > some general guidance about how to appr=
oach the problem? Thanks very
> > much for your help.
> >
> > I'm using the=
 Python interface to Cantera v1.6.
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Paul
